question: Which king destroyed the bronze serpent Moses had made because people were worshiping it?
explanation: King Hezekiah broke into pieces the bronze serpent Moses had made, which had become an object of worship.

verses.kjv: He removed the high places, and brake the images, and cut down the groves, and brake in pieces the brasen serpent that Moses had made: for unto those days the children of Israel did burn incense to it: and he called it Nehushtan.

question: Which king was struck with leprosy for burning incense in the temple?
explanation: King Uzziah became angry with the priests and leprosy broke out on his forehead in the temple.

verses.kjv:
Then Uzziah was wroth, and
had a censer in his hand to burn incense: and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy even rose up in his forehead before the priests in the house of the LORD, from beside the incense altar.

question: Which king had the longest reign over Judah?
explanation: Manasseh reigned 55 years in Jerusalem, the longest reign of any king of Judah.

verses.kjv:
Manasseh
was twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and five years in Jerusalem:

question: Which king made a rash vow that led to his daughter's death?
explanation: Jephthah vowed to sacrifice whatever came out of his house first, which was his only daughter.

verses.kjv:
And Jephthah vowed a vow unto the LORD, and said, If thou shalt without fail deliver the children of Ammon into mine hands,
Then it shall be, that whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the children of Ammon, shall surely be the LORD’S, and I will offer it up for a burnt offering.

question: Which king had to crawl on the ground eating grass like an animal?
explanation: Nebuchadnezzar was driven from people and ate grass like cattle until he acknowledged God's sovereignty.

verses.kjv:
The same hour was the thing fulfilled upon Nebuchadnezzar: and he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles
feathers, and his nails like birds’
claws.

question: Which king burned Jeremiah's scroll?
explanation: King Jehoiakim cut off the scroll with a scribe's knife and threw it into the fire.

verses.kjv:
And it came to pass,
that when Jehudi had read three or four leaves, he cut it with the penknife, and cast
it into the fire that
was on the hearth, until all the roll was consumed in the fire that
was on the hearth.

question: Who was the last king of Judah before the Babylonian exile?
explanation: Zedekiah was the last king of Judah before Jerusalem fell to Babylon.

verses.kjv:
And it came to pass in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, in the tenth
day of the month,
that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came, he, and all his host, against Jerusalem, and pitched against it; and they built forts against it round about.
And the city was besieged unto the eleventh year of king Zedekiah.
And on the ninth
day of the
fourth month the famine prevailed in the city, and there was no bread for the people of the land.
And the city was broken up, and all the men of war
fled by night by the way of the gate between two walls, which
is by the king’s garden: (now the Chaldees
were against the city round about:) and
the king went the way toward the plain.
And the army of the Chaldees pursued after the king, and overtook him in the plains of Jericho: and all his army were scattered from him.
So they took the king, and brought him up to the king of Babylon to Riblah; and they gave judgment upon him.
And they slew the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and put out the eyes of Zedekiah, and bound him with fetters of brass, and carried him to Babylon.

question: Which king killed his brother to secure the throne?
explanation: Abimelech went to his father's house and murdered his seventy brothers on one stone.

verses.kjv:
And he went unto his father’s house at Ophrah, and slew his brethren the sons of Jerubbaal,
being threescore and ten persons, upon one stone: notwithstanding yet Jotham the youngest son of Jerubbaal was left; for he hid himself.

question: Who was king of Judah when Jerusalem fell to Babylon?
explanation: In the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched against Jerusalem.

verses.kjv:
And it came to pass in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, in the tenth
day of the month,
that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came, he, and all his host, against Jerusalem, and pitched against it; and they built forts against it round about.

question: Which king had the longest reign in the Bible, ruling for 55 years?
explanation: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem fifty-five years.

verses.kjv:
Manasseh
was twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and five years in Jerusalem:

question: Which king was struck with leprosy for trying to burn incense in the temple?
explanation: King Uzziah became angry when priests confronted him, and leprosy broke out on his forehead.

verses.kjv:
Then Uzziah was wroth, and
had a censer in his hand to burn incense: and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy even rose up in his forehead before the priests in the house of the LORD, from beside the incense altar.

question: Who was the king of Judah when Jerusalem fell to Babylon?
explanation: King Zedekiah witnessed his sons being killed, then had his eyes put out before being taken to Babylon.

verses.kjv: And they slew the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and put out the eyes of Zedekiah, and bound him with fetters of brass, and carried him to Babylon.

question: Which king restored the temple worship during his reign?
explanation: In the first month of his reign, Hezekiah opened the doors of the temple and repaired them.

verses.kjv: He in the first year of his reign, in the first month, opened the doors of the house of the LORD, and repaired them.

question: Which king was eaten by worms for accepting worship?
explanation: Immediately an angel struck Herod down because he did not give praise to God, and he was eaten by worms.

verses.kjv: And immediately the angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the glory: and he was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost.

question: Which king had a navy that brought him gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks?
explanation: The king had a fleet of trading ships that brought gold, silver, ivory, apes and baboons.

verses.kjv: For the king had at sea a navy of Tharshish with the navy of Hiram: once in three years came the navy of Tharshish, bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks.

question: Which king had a sundial that went backward as a sign?
explanation: Then the prophet Isaiah called on the Lord, and the Lord made the shadow go back the ten steps it had gone down on the stairway of Ahaz.

verses.kjv: And Isaiah the prophet cried unto the LORD: and he brought the shadow ten degrees backward, by which it had gone down in the dial of Ahaz.

question: Which king of Judah became king at age eight?
explanation: Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem thirty-one years.

verses.kjv:
Josiah
was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned thirty and one years in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name
was
 Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah of Boscath.

question: Which king of Israel was killed by Jehu?
explanation: Then Jehu drew his bow and shot Joram between the shoulders. The arrow pierced his heart and he slumped down in his chariot.

verses.kjv: And Jehu drew a bow with his full strength, and smote Jehoram between his arms, and the arrow went out at his heart, and he sunk down in his chariot.

question: Which king walked around naked and barefoot for three years as a sign?
explanation: The Lord said, 'Just as my servant Isaiah has gone stripped and barefoot for three years, as a sign against Egypt and Cush.'

verses.kjv:
And the LORD said, Like as my servant Isaiah hath walked naked and barefoot three years
for a sign and wonder upon Egypt and upon Ethiopia;

question: Which king was struck with leprosy for entering the temple to burn incense?
explanation: Uzziah became angry. While he was raging at the priests, leprosy broke out on his forehead.

verses.kjv:
Then Uzziah was wroth, and
had a censer in his hand to burn incense: and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy even rose up in his forehead before the priests in the house of the LORD, from beside the incense altar.

question: Which king made a rash vow that led to his daughter's sacrifice?
explanation: And Jephthah made a vow to the Lord: 'If you give the Ammonites into my hands, whatever comes out of the door of my house to meet me will be the Lord's.'

verses.kjv:
And Jephthah vowed a vow unto the LORD, and said, If thou shalt without fail deliver the children of Ammon into mine hands,
Then it shall be, that whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the children of Ammon, shall surely be the LORD’S, and I will offer it up for a burnt offering.

question: Which king had his eyes gouged out by the Babylonians?
explanation: They killed the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes. Then they put out his eyes, bound him with bronze shackles and took him to Babylon.

verses.kjv: And they slew the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and put out the eyes of Zedekiah, and bound him with fetters of brass, and carried him to Babylon.

question: Which king of Judah became king at age seven?
explanation: Joash was seven years old when he began to reign.

verses.kjv:
Seven years old
was Jehoash when he began to reign.

question: Which king reigned for only seven days?
explanation: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned in Tirzah seven days.

verses.kjv:
In the twenty and seventh year of Asa king of Judah did Zimri reign seven days in Tirzah. And the people
were encamped against Gibbethon, which
belonged to the Philistines.

question: Which king of Israel reigned for only seven days before committing suicide?
explanation: Zimri reigned in Tirzah seven days. When the army heard that Zimri had plotted against the king and murdered him, Zimri went into the citadel and set the palace on fire around him and died.

verses.kjv:
In the twenty and seventh year of Asa king of Judah did Zimri reign seven days in Tirzah. And the people
were encamped against Gibbethon, which
belonged to the Philistines.

question: What was the name of the captain of the host of king Saul?
explanation: 1 Samuel 14:50 names Abner (the son of Ner, Saul’s uncle) as the captain of Saul’s host.

verses.kjv: And the name of Saul's wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz: and the name of the captain of his host was Abner, the son of Ner, Saul's uncle.

question: What was the name of Saul’s wife?
explanation: 1 Samuel 14:50 states that Saul’s wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz.

verses.kjv: And the name of Saul's wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz: and the name of the captain of his host was Abner, the son of Ner, Saul's uncle.

question: What was the name of Saul’s son who reigned two years over Israel?
explanation: 2 Samuel 2:10 says Ish-bosheth, Saul’s son, was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel and reigned two years.

verses.kjv: Ish-bosheth Saul's son was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and reigned two years. But the house of Judah followed David.

question: What was Ish-bosheth’s age when he began to reign over Israel?
explanation: 2 Samuel 2:10 states that Ish-bosheth was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel.

verses.kjv: Ish-bosheth Saul's son was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and reigned two years. But the house of Judah followed David.

question: How many sons did David have that were born to him in Hebron?
explanation: 2 Samuel 3:2 begins listing David’s sons born in Hebron, stating that sons were born unto David there.

verses.kjv: And unto David were sons born in Hebron: and his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess;

question: Who was David’s firstborn son born in Hebron?
explanation: 2 Samuel 3:2 says David’s firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess.

verses.kjv: And unto David were sons born in Hebron: and his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess;

question: Who was the second son of David born in Hebron, and who was his mother?
explanation: 2 Samuel 3:3 names the second son as Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.

verses.kjv: And his second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;

question: What was the name of the king of Geshur whose daughter Maacah was David’s wife?
explanation: 2 Samuel 3:3 names Maacah as the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur.

verses.kjv: And his second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;

question: What city did David build round about after taking the strong hold?
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:9 says David dwelt in the fort and built round about from Millo and inward.

verses.kjv: So David dwelt in the fort, and called it the city of David. And David built round about from Millo and inward.

question: What did Hiram king of Tyre send to David after David was established as king?
choices: Messengers, cedar trees, carpenters, and masons
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:11 says Hiram sent messengers, cedar trees, carpenters, and masons, and they built David a house.

verses.kjv: And Hiram king of Tyre sent messengers to David, and cedar trees, and carpenters, and masons: and they built David an house.

question: What did David perceive about the LORD after he was established as king over Israel?
choices: That the LORD had established him king, and exalted his kingdom for his people Israel’s sake
That the LORD had rejected him forever
That the LORD would move the kingdom to Egypt
That the LORD would give him no more sons
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:12 says David perceived the LORD had established him and exalted his kingdom for Israel’s sake.

verses.kjv: And David perceived that the LORD had established him king over Israel, and that he had exalted his kingdom for his people Israel's sake.

question: According to 2 Samuel 5:13, what did David take to himself after coming from Hebron?
choices: More concubines and wives out of Jerusalem
Only gold and silver from Tyre
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:13 says David took more concubines and wives out of Jerusalem after coming from Hebron.

verses.kjv: And David took him more concubines and wives out of Jerusalem, after he was come from Hebron: and there were yet sons and daughters born to David.

question: What did the Philistines do when they heard that David was anointed king over Israel?
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:17 says the Philistines came up to seek David when they heard he was anointed king.

verses.kjv: But when the Philistines heard that they had anointed David king over Israel, all the Philistines came up to seek David; and David heard of it, and went down to the hold.

question: Where did the Philistines spread themselves when they came up to seek David?
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:18 says the Philistines came and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

verses.kjv: The Philistines also came and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

question: What did David call the place where the LORD broke forth upon his enemies like a breach of waters?
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:20 says David came to Baal-perazim and said the LORD broke forth upon his enemies like a breach of waters.

verses.kjv: And David came to Baal-perazim, and David smote them there, and said, The LORD hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters. Therefore he called the name of that place Baal-perazim.

question: After David smote the Philistines, what did the Philistines leave behind at Baal-perazim?
explanation: 2 Samuel 5:21 says the Philistines left their images, and David and his men burned them.

verses.kjv: And there they left their images, and David and his men burned them.

question: What did David do when he brought the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom to the city of David?
choices: Offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD
Fastened it to a new cart
Set it in the temple of Dagon
explanation: 2 Samuel 6:17 says David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD after setting the ark in its place.

verses.kjv: And they brought in the ark of the LORD, and set it in his place, in the midst of the tabernacle that David had pitched for it: and David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.

question: After bringing up the ark, what did David do for all the people?
choices: Dealt to every one a cake of bread, a good piece of flesh, and a flagon of wine
explanation: 2 Samuel 6:19 says David gave to every one of all the people a cake of bread, a good piece of flesh, and a flagon of wine.

verses.kjv: And he dealt among all the people, even among the whole multitude of Israel, as well to the women as men, to every one a cake of bread, and a good piece of flesh, and a flagon of wine. So all the people departed every one to his house.

question: When Michal despised David, what did David say he would be yet more vile than?
explanation: 2 Samuel 6:22 records David saying, "I will yet be more vile than thus" and would be base in his own sight.

verses.kjv:
And David said unto Michal, It was before the LORD, which chose me before thy father, and before all his house, to appoint me ruler over the people of the LORD, over Israel: therefore will I play before the LORD.
And I will yet be more vile than thus, and will be base in mine own sight: and of the maidservants which thou hast spoken of, of them shall I be had in honour.

question: What did the LORD say would come out of David’s bowels to establish his kingdom?
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:12 says God would set up David’s seed after him, which would proceed out of his bowels, and establish his kingdom.

verses.kjv: And when thy days be fulfilled, and thou shalt sleep with thy fathers, I will set up thy seed after thee, which shall proceed out of thy bowels, and I will establish his kingdom.

question: What did the LORD promise to establish forever for David’s seed in 2 Samuel 7:13?
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:13 says God would establish the throne of his kingdom forever.

verses.kjv: He shall build an house for my name, and I will stablish the throne of his kingdom for ever.

question: What did the LORD say He would be to David’s seed, and what would David’s seed be to Him?
choices: A father; and he shall be a son
A king; and he shall be a servant
A judge; and he shall be a prophet
A warrior; and he shall be a priest
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 says, "I will be his father, and he shall be my son."

verses.kjv: I will be his father, and he shall be my son. If he commit iniquity, I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men:

question: When the LORD chastened David’s seed for iniquity, what did He say He would use?
choices: The rod of men and the stripes of the children of men
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 says God would chasten him with the rod of men and with the stripes of the children of men.

verses.kjv: I will be his father, and he shall be my son. If he commit iniquity, I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men:

question: What did the LORD say would not depart from David’s seed as it departed from Saul?
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:15 says God’s mercy would not depart from him as it departed from Saul.

verses.kjv: But my mercy shall not depart away from him, as I took it from Saul, whom I put away before thee.

question: What did the LORD promise would be established for ever before David in 2 Samuel 7:16?
explanation: 2 Samuel 7:16 says David’s house and kingdom would be established forever before him, and his throne established forever.

verses.kjv: And thine house and thy kingdom shall be established for ever before thee: thy throne shall be established for ever.
